awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Olya Mandelshtam is "Asymptotics of the Asymmetric Simple Exclusion Process." The host institution for the fellowship is Brown University, and the sponsoring scientist is Richard Kenyon.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The ASEP is a non-equilibrium particle model in which particles hop left and right on the sites of a one-dimensional lattice such that there is at most one particle per site. Variants of the ASEP are deeply linked with classes of symmetric functions called Macdonald polynomials, a rich family of polynomials associated to different Lie types, which is at the forefront of much current research in algebraic combinatorics. A major gap in understanding Macdonald and related polynomials is that they are profoundly complex and difficult to compute, and in many cases (with the exception of type A) there are no known explicit formulas for their coefficients. Thus understanding the underlying combinatorial structures of the associated particle models is a powerful tool for studying them. In several cases, combinatorial objects have been found to interpolate between the polynomials and probabilities of the particle models, such as alternating tableaux, staircase tableaux, and multiline queues. Developing combinatorial objects to study the connection between the multispecies ASEP on a circle and the type A Macdonald polynomials has been the focus of the PIs MSPRF research. The three years of the PI's research on this topic resulted in five published papers, four conference proceedings, eleven invited conference talks, and numerous seminar talks in work with seven collaborators from all over the world. Notably, with Sylvie Corteel and Lauren Williams, the PI found a multiline queue formula for the type A Macdonald polynomial that specializes to probabilities the multispecies ASEP on a circle. The same group, along with Jim Haglund and Sarah Mason, introduced quasisymmetric Macdonald polynomials in terms of multiline queues. They also found compact formulas for the modified Macdonald polynomials, which in turn led to a new conjectural formula that would connect the modified Macdonald polynomials to the zero range process. The PI aims to continue this fruitful research direction, both by generalizing existing formulas, and by discovering new combinatorial objects, to further study a larger class of particle models and obtain new formulas for families of Macdonald (and related) polynomials. 


Last Modified: 12/17/2023
Modified by: Olya Mandelshtam
